facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 6 to 12 of 1963 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 6 to 12 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and decree dated February 2, 1959 of Madras High Court in Writ Petition Nos. 1, 2, 202, 203, 204, 309 and 373 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated February 2, 1959 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition Nos. 1. 2, 202, 203, 204, 309 and 373 of 1958.

facts.text: Investigations conducted by Geological Survey of India in 1947 revealed deposits of lignite in South Arcot District of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Investigations conducted by the Geological Survey of India in 1947 revealed deposits of lignite in the South Arcot District of the State of Madras,

facts.text: Exploratory mining operations commenced by Government of Madras after discovery of lignite deposits.

anchor.surface_text: and exploratory mining operations were commenced by the Government of Madras. Discovery of deposits of lignite led to speculation in lands.

facts.text: Discovery of lignite led to speculation in lands.

anchor.surface_text: Discovery of deposits of lignite led to speculation in lands. On October 6, 1948, the Government of Madras issued a Press-Note

facts.text: Government of Madras issued Press-Note on October 6, 1948 announcing proposed legislation to compel sellers of land purchased on or after a date in 1947 to sell to Government at purchase rate.

anchor.surface_text: On October 6, 1948, the Government of Madras issued a Press-Note announcing that the Government proposed to undertake legislation reserving power to compel any person who had purchased land on or after a date to be prescribed in 1947 in the lignite-bearing areas to sell such lands to the Government at the rate at which it was purchased.

facts.text: Government advised owners of lignite-bearing lands in Vriddhachalam and Cuddalore taluks not to sell to speculators.

anchor.surface_text: The Government also advised the owners of the lignite-bearing lands in the Vriddhachalam and Cuddalore taluks not to sell their lands to speculators.

facts.text: Government of Madras published Bill to amend Land Acquisition Act on January 7, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On January 7, 1953, the Government of Madras published a Bill to amend the Land Acquisition Act 1 of 1894 in certain respects.

facts.text: Bill passed by State Legislature on June 2, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Bill was duly passed by the State Legislature on June 2, 1953 and received the assent of the President.

facts.text: Madras Lignite Acquisition of Land Act XI of 1953 published on June 10, 1953 and came into force on August 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It was published as an Act on June 10, 1953 and came into force on August 20, 1953. By this Act substantially three provisions are made

facts.text: Act provides compensation for lignite-bearing lands based on market value on April 28, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: that compensation for acquisition of lignitebearing lands under the Land Acquisition Act as amended, is to be assessed on the market value of the land prevailing on April 28, 1947,

facts.text: Notifications under s.4(1) of Land Acquisition Act issued between January and May 1957 for lands in Vriddhachalam taluk, South Arcot District.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this Act, notifications under s. 4(1) of the Land Acquisition Act were issued between the months of January and May 1957 notifying for acquisition certain lands in Vriddachalam taluk of the South Arcot District.

facts.text: Notifications under s.6 followed s.4(1) notifications.

anchor.surface_text: These notifications were followed by notifications under s. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act.

facts.text: Land Acquisition Officer made awards under s.11 between May and November 1957 assessing compensation on 1947 market value, ignoring post-1947 non-agricultural improvements.

anchor.surface_text: Between the months of May and November 1957 the Land Acquisition Officer made his awards under s. 11 of the Land Acquisition Act assessing compensation on the basis of market value of the lands on April 28, 1947 and ignoring in the computation of compensation the value of houses built or other non-agricultural improvements made on the land since that date.

facts.text: Owners filed writ petitions under Art.226 in Madras High Court challenging validity of awards and Madras Act XI of 1953 under Art.31(2).

anchor.surface_text: The owners of the lands affected by these awards submitted petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Judicature at Madras challenging the validity of the awards on the ground that the provisions of Madras Act XI of 1953 violated the fundamental right of the owners of the lands under Art. 31(2) of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court upheld petitioners' contentions and declared awards invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the contention of the petitioners and declared that the awards made on the basis of the provisions of Madras Act XI of 1953 could not be sustained.

facts.text: State of Madras preferred appeals to Supreme Court with certificate under Art.132.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the High Court, these appeals have been preferred by the State of Madras, with certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under Art. 132 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 3, 1964 by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: March 3, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-Whether ss. 2 and 3 of the Madras Lignite

facts.text: Supreme Court held ss.2 and 3 of Madras Act XI of 1953 invalid as infringing Art.31(2).

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the provisions which require the Land Acquisition Officer and the Court to assess compensation of the land compulsorily acquired only on the market value of the land on April 28, 1947,

facts.text: Appeals dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed. The respondents in this group of appeals, except in appeal No. 11 of 1963,

facts.text: April 28, 1947 was the date lignite deposits were discovered.

anchor.surface_text: It may be assumed that April 28, 1947, was the date on which lignite deposits were discovered in the areas to which the Act is extended.

facts.text: In appeal No.11/1963, State to pay costs of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore in appeal No. 11 of 1963 alone, the State of Madras will pay the costs of the respondent.

facts.text: Land owners claimed compensation at market value on date of s.4(1) notification.

anchor.surface_text: They claimed that the Land Acquisition Officer was bound to award compensation for acquisition of their lands and buildings at the market value prevailing on the respective dates of the notifications under s. 4(1),

facts.text: Awards ignored value of houses and non-agricultural improvements post-1947.

anchor.surface_text: assessing compensation on the basis of market value of the lads on April 28, 1947 and ignoring in the computation of compensation the value of houses built or other non-agricultural improvements

The owners of the lands affected by these awards submitted petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Judicature at Madras challenging the validity of the awards on the ground that the provisions of Madras Act XI of 1953 violated the fundamental right of the owners of the lands under Art. 31(2) of the Constitution.
Against the order passed by the High Court, these appeals have been preferred by the State of Madras, with certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under Art. 132 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether ss. 2 and 3 of the Madras Lignite Acquisition of Land Act XI of 1953 which seek to amend the Land Acquisition Act 1 of 1894 in their application to acquisition of lignite-bearing lands are invalid because they infringe the fundamental right under Art. 31 of the Constitution of owners of lands whose property is to be compulsorily acquired

anchor.surface_text: Whether ss. 2 and 3 of the Madras Lignite Acquisition of Land Act XI of 1953 which seek to amend the Land Acquisition Act 1 of 1894 in their application to acquisition of lignite-bearing lands are invalid because they infringe the fundamental right under Art. 31 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the provision in Madras Act XI of 1953 fixing compensation for acquisition of lignite-bearing lands on the market value prevailing on April 28, 1947 infringes Art. 31(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Fixation of compensation for compulsory acquisition of lands notified many years after that date, on the market value prevailing on the date on which lignite was discovered is wholly arbitrary and inconsistent with the letter and spirit of Art. 31(2)

issues.text: Whether the provision in Madras Act XI of 1953 denying compensation for non-agricultural improvements made after April 28, 1947 infringes Art. 31(2) of the Constitution

Whether the power reserved under s. 17 of the Land Acquisition Act as amended by s. 2 of Madras Act XI of 1953 to take possession of lands under the emergency clause for working lignite mines is invalid

Whether it is possible by enacting legislation after the amendment of Art. 31(2) by the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955 which is not given any retrospective operation to provide that compensation for compulsory acquisition of land may be fixed on the basis of market value prevailing on a date anterior to the date of the issue of the notification under s. 4(1)

anchor.surface_text: Madras Act XI of 1953 was passed before the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955 was enacted, and we have to deal with the question of the validity of the Act in the light of the constitutional provisions contained in Art. 31 before the constitutional amendment.

arguments.claim: No evidence that 1947 Press-Note or discovery created anticipation justifying anterior date fixation

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence that any scheme for acquisition of land for mining of lignite was prepared in 1947 by the Government of Madras. The mining operations in 1947 must, in the very nature of things, have been exploratory.

holdings.text: Fixation of compensation for compulsory acquisition of lands notified many years after that date, on the market value prevailing on the date on which lignite was discovered is wholly arbitrary and inconsistent with the letter and spirit of Art. 31(2)

anchor.surface_text: Fixation of compensation for compulsory acquisition of lands notified many years after that date, on the market value prevailing on the date on which lignite was discovered is wholly arbitrary and inconsistent with the letter and spirit of Art. 31(2)

holdings.reasoning_summary: Anterior date lacks nexus to acquisition; no evidence of scheme in 1947 or speculation from press-note justifying freeze; denies just equivalent per Bela Banerjee principle

holdings.text: The provision which denies to the owner of land compensation for non-agricultural improvements made by him since April 28, 1947, also infringes the protection of Art. 31(2)
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(a) LAA defines land to include superstructures and attached things; acquisition takes entirety; excluding post-1947 non-agri value deprives just equivalent

holdings.text: The provisions which require the Land Acquisition Officer and the Court to assess compensation of the land compulsorily acquired only on the market value of the land on April 28, 1947, together with the value of agricultural improvements on the land commenced, made or effected after that date, and before the date of the publication of the notification under s. 4(1), without taking into consideration the value of non-agricultural improvements made after that date, must be regarded as invalid

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the provisions which require the Land Acquisition Officer and the Court to assess compensation of the land compulsorily acquired only on the market value of the land on April 28, 1947,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines arbitrary anterior fixation and exclusion of improvements; no justification or evidence for justness; post-war appreciation not proven attributable to state; infringes Art.31(2) guarantee of just equivalent

holdings.text: We are not called upon to express any opinion on the question whether the power reserved under s. 17 of the Land Acquisition Act as amended by s. 2 of Madras Act XI of 1953 to take possession of lands under the emergency clause for the purpose of working lignite mines in the areas to which the Madras Lignite Acquisition of Land Act, 1953, extends is invalid
holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not argued by parties; not considered by High Court

holdings.text: The Constitution therefore conferred by Art. 31(2) fundamental right upon every person, protecting his property against compulsory acquisition otherwise than by authority of law, and without just indemnification for loss suffered by him

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution therefore conferred by Art. 31(2) fundamental right upon every person, protecting his property against compulsory acquisition otherwise than by authority of law, and without just indemnification for loss suffered by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Art.31(1)-(2) with precedents on eminent domain requiring quantum fixed or principles for just equivalent

holdings.text: Under s. 3(a) of the Land Acquisition Act land is defined as including benefits to arise out of land, and things attached to the earth or permanently fastened to anything attached to the earth

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual definition; applies to include all improvements in acquisition

anchor.surface_text: In The State of West Bengal v. Mrs. Bela Banerjee and others 1  this Court observed that when under Entry 42 List III the Legislature was given discretionary power to, lay down the principles which should govern determination of the amount to be given to the owner of the property appropriated, such principles must ensure that what is, determined as payable must be a just equivalent of what the owner has been deprived of

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v Bela Banerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: Principles for compensation must ensure just equivalent of the property deprived; fixing market value ceiling on anterior date like December 31, 1946 is arbitrary and violates Art. 31(2)
precedents.cited_holding: The West Bengal Land Development and Planning Act, 1948 limiting compensation to market value on December 31, 1946 is ultra vires Art. 31(2)

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State of Madras relying upon the following observation of Patanjali Sastri, C.J., in Mrs. Bela Banerjees case 1  at p. 564 The fixing of an anterior date for the ascertainment of Value may number, in certain circumstances, be  1  1954 S.C.R. 558. .lm15 a violation of the companystitutional requirement as, for instance, when the proposed scheme of acquisition becomes known before it is launched and prices rise sharply in anticipation of the benefits to be derived under it

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v Bela Banerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: Fixing an anterior date for valuation may not in certain circumstances violate constitutional requirement, e.g., if prices rise in anticipation of acquisition

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed. The respondents in this group of appeals, except in appeal No. 11 of 1963, have number appeared in this, Court. Therefore in appeal No. 11 of 1963 alone, the State of Madras will pay the companyts of the respondent.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; provisions of Madras Lignite Acquisition of Land Act XI of 1953 held invalid for infringing Art. 31(2) by fixing compensation on market value as of April 28, 1947 and excluding non-agricultural improvements made after that date.
directions: State of Madras to pay costs of the respondent in appeal No. 11 of 1963
